**Limits of Indemnity Applicable**
1. The following insured items are subjected to a limit of $250 per article and up to one-third of the Benefit Limit.
    a. Valuables;
    b. Musical instruments;
    c. Photographic equipment;
    d. Bicycle/Pedal Cycle;
    e. Sporting and fishing equipment.
2. Where any insured item consists of articles in a pair or set, We will not pay more than the value of any particular part or parts which such article or articles, may have as part of such pair or set; nor more than a proportionate part of the insured value of the pair or set.

**Exclusions Applicable to Section 12**
No benefit will be payable under Section 12:
1. Any gross negligence committed by Your Maid.
2. Consequential loss or damage of any kind.
3. Arcing, sparking, scorching or heat damage where there is no flame.
4. Irregularities in the power supply.

# OPTIONAL COVERS
(Applicable if the section(s) are indicated as covered in the Policy Schedule)
questions: How does the $250 per article limit and the one-third Benefit Limit cap apply to claims involving valuables, musical instruments, photographic equipment, bicycles, and sporting or fishing equipment, and how does this interact with the pair or set valuation rule?

In the event of loss or damage to an insured item that is part of a pair or set, how is the maximum payable amount determined under the pair-and-sets clause, and how does this affect claims for partial loss within the set?

What types of damages or losses are explicitly excluded under Section 12, and how do these exclusions affect claims arising from incidents involving power supply irregularities or heat damage without flame?

If a claim involves damage caused by gross negligence of Your Maid, how does the Section 12 exclusion impact the eligibility for benefits, and are there any exceptions or conditions to this exclusion?
How are consequential losses treated under Section 12 exclusions, and what examples of consequential loss might be denied coverage under this policy section?
When claiming for damage caused by arcing, sparking, or scorching without flame, what documentation or evidence is required to determine if the exclusion applies under Section 12?

How does the limit of indemnity for photographic equipment compare to that for sporting and fishing equipment, and what combined limits apply if multiple item types are lost or damaged in a single claim?
In cases where an insured bicycle is part of a set with accessories, how does the policy determine the maximum payable amount under the pair or set limitation and the $250 per article cap?
If an insured item exceeds the $250 per article limit but is not part of a pair or set, how is the claim amount calculated relative to the one-third Benefit Limit?
How do the Section 12 exclusions interact with any optional covers that might be indicated in the Policy Schedule, particularly regarding negligence or power supply issues?
What is the process for proving the value of an insured item that is part of a pair or set when submitting a claim, and how does this affect the indemnity limit applied?
Are there any circumstances under which the limit of $250 per article can be exceeded for valuables or musical instruments, such as with optional covers or endorsements?
How does the policy define and apply the term 'consequential loss' in the context of Section 12 exclusions, and what impact does this have on claims for indirect damages?
If a claim involves damage from irregularities in the power supply, what exclusions apply, and how might this affect claims for electronic equipment listed under insured items?
How does the policy handle claims for multiple insured items within the same category (e.g., several pieces of photographic equipment) in relation to the per article limit and overall Benefit Limit?
What documentation or evidence is required to demonstrate that damage was not caused by arcing, sparking, scorching, or heat damage without flame to avoid Section 12 exclusions?
In the event of a claim involving Your Maid's actions, how is gross negligence defined and assessed under Section 12 exclusions, and what impact does this have on claim approval?
How do the limits of indemnity and exclusions under Section 12 apply when an insured item is damaged due to a power surge caused by irregularities in the power supply?

If an insured item is part of a pair or set and only one part is lost or damaged, how does the policy determine the proportionate part of the insured value payable, and what documentation supports this valuation?
How do the Section 12 exclusions and limits of indemnity interact when a claim involves multiple causes of loss, such as negligence by Your Maid combined with power supply irregularities?
